title: In dialogue writing, is it better to put 'said' before or after the character speaking it? - Quora

response.answer_text: John said, “That’s my coat.” “That’s my coat,” John said. The truth is, there is no rule about where to use “said.” Before or after and even during an action is unimportant. What is important is the rhythm of your work, the pacing of your dialogue. Changing from one to the other can make your dialogue sound more lifelike. John said, “That’s my coat.” Jack said, “No it’s not. Pete said, “What are you arguing about?”Jane said, “Shut up. I’m trying to study.” Now, let’s do that one all over again: Jack took a coat off the pile on the floor and shoved his left arm into a sleeve. “Hey,” John said. “That’s my coat.”Jack stared at him. “No, it’s not. See? This is the one with the torn pocket.”John snatched the collar of the coat and pulled it off Jack’s arm. “I tore that pocket six months ago. It’s my coat.”“It not!” “Is so!”“What,” Pete demanded, glaring at the two boys, “are you guys arguing about?”Jane looked up from her textbook. “Shut up, all of you. I’m trying to study.” I used “said” once, yet any reader could figure out who was talking whether I’d used the word before or after the quote. As above, it’s the pacing and rhythm of the dialogue that really matters, not the placement of the word “said.” Use dialogue to create mental pictures in the readers’ minds so they can both see and hear what’s going on.

For me, it’s a sense of rhythm, but also needs to clarify who is speaking when there might be some doubt. So, I suggest writing it both ways to see which works better in a given instance. Use it to introduce two characters speaking and eliminate it thereafter unless needed to keep it clear who is speaking. Also, keep in mind that each character should have a distinctive voice that helps us know who is speaking. Anytime you write dialogue, read through it without the character designations to see if you can tell who’s speaking. If both characters sound the same then you need to do more work on them to find their individual voices.
